stem: A client is in the PACU following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. Based on the documentation in the PACU Respiratory & Temperature Surveillance Log, which finding is the most criticalEARLY indicator of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH)?

options.text: The rise in End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2) to 74 mmHg
The increase in heart rate to 138 bpm
The muscle rigidity of the jaw (Masseter Spasm)

rationale.correct: The most critical **EARLY** indicator of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) is the **sudden, unexplained rise in End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2) (a1)** despite adequate ventilation. In MH, the hypermetabolic state produces massive amounts of CO2 as the first byproduct. While Jaw rigidity (a4) and Tachycardia (a2) are also early signs, the **ETCO2 rise** is often the very first sign detected on the monitors. Temperature rise (a3) is actually a LATE sign of MH.
clinicalPearls: MH is a calcium-dysregulation problem triggered by 'Vane' gases (Isoflurane) or 'Succs' (Succinylcholine).
Earliest signs: Hypercapnia (High CO2), Tachycardia, and Muscle Rigidity.
Latest signs: Fever (can rise 1 degree every 5 mins), Myoglobinuria (Cola urine).

questionTrap.trap: Choosing 'Fever' or 'Temp rise' because the condition is called 'Hyperthermia.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Despite the name, Malignant Hyperthermia starts with metabolic chemistry (CO2), not heat. Fever only happens once the cells are already cooking.

exhibits.title: Nurses Notes
exhibits.content: 1430: Client is increasingly tachypneic. Jaw appears rigid (Lockjaw) when attempting to insert an oral airway. Skin is mottled and diaphoretic. No fever noted yet.
